name: West African Music
description: Traditional and regional popular music from the Western portion of Sub-Saharan Africa.

children.name: Afro-Funk
children.description: Strongly mixed with traditional and more modern genres in sub-Saharan West Africa.

children.name: Afro-Rock
children.description: Incorporates West African influences; initially emerged in the early 1970s.

children.name: Afrobeat
children.description: Merges West African styles such as traditional Yoruba Music and Highlife with elements of Funk and  Jazz, typically resulting in extended improvisatory jams with call-and-response vocals.

children.name: Akan Music
children.description: Music of the Akan people of Ghana and Côte d'Ivoire, including a variety of traditional and neo-traditional styles which are based on some of the oldest traditions in West Africa.

children.name: Balani Show
children.description: Emerged in the late 1990s in Mali; peaks at around 170BPM and prominently features looping, cut-up balafon samples.

children.name: Dagomba Music
children.description: Music of the Dagomba people of northern Ghana.

children.name: Ewe Music
children.description: Music of the Ewe people, found in southern Togo, southeastern Ghana and southwestern Benin.

children.name: Fon Music
children.description: The traditions of the Fon people, originating in central and southeastern Benin as well as the southwestern region of Nigeria.

children.name: Fula Music
children.description: Music of the Fula, Fulani, or Fulɓe people, one of the largest ethnic groups in the Sahel region, present from the far West African countries of Senegal and Mauritania to Central African Cameroon with the biggest population located in Nigeria.

children.name: Griot Music
children.description: Type of hereditary professional caste in West African Music culture that preserves tradition.

children.name: Gumbe
children.description: Vocal and percussive tradition from Guinea-Bissau developed in the 1970s as a fusion of various traditional genres in the country; sometimes used as a catch-all term for the music of Guinea-Bissau in general.

children.name: Hausa Music
children.description: Hausa are one of the largest ethnic groups in Africa, living mainly in northern Nigeria and southern Niger in west Africa.

children.name: Highlife
children.description: Originally began along the Ghanaian coast in the 1920s as a blend of western brass band instrumentation and rhythms with traditional Akan Music and Dagomba Music.

children.name: Hipco
children.description: Developed in Liberia, often featuring conscious and political lyrics and influences from local dance styles.

children.name: Hiplife
children.description: Fusion of Ghanaian Highlife with Hip Hop.

children.name: Igbo Music
children.description: Music of the Igbo people, who live mainly in a region of southeastern Nigeria often known as "Igboland".

children.name: Kabye Folk Music
children.description: Traditional Folk Music of the Kabye people of northern Togo, including some of the most singular styles that can be found in West Africa.

children.name: Kru Music
children.description: Music of the Kru peoples indigenous to Liberia and Ivory Coast.

children.name: Mande Music
children.description: Encompasses the diverse forms of the Mande peoples, a group of West African ethnic groups who speak any of the Mande languages.

children.name: Mossi Music
children.description: Music of the Mossi people of Burkina Faso.

children.name: Songhai Music
children.description: Music of the Songhai people of Mali, who descend from the ancient Songhai Empire which once ruled most of interior West Africa.

children.name: Tradi-moderne ivoirien
children.description: Blends traditional Ivorian songs, rhythms and instruments with modern electric and electronic instruments.

children.name: Wassoulou
children.description: Traditionally sung by women and containing lyrics relating to women's issues such as childbearing and fertility.

children.name: Wolof Music
children.description: Music of the Wolof people of Senegal and The Gambia comprising a wide variety of West African Music traditions influenced by nearby cultures.

children.name: Yoruba Music
children.description: Music of the Yoruba people of southwestern Nigeria and Benin, comprising a variety of ancient and modern traditions crucial to West African Music.

children.name: Zouglou
children.description: Ivorian dance music that began in the early 1990s, with socially conscious lyrics and driving rhythms.
